title: Where did the term ghetto originate? - Quora

response.answer_text: The word was first used in Venice to denote the district of Cannaregio where the Venetian Jews were restricted to live beginning in 1516. The district was enclosed by guarded gates and no resident was allowed to leave from 6 p.m. every night to 12 p.m. the next day. The boats of the Christian guards scoured the surrounding canals to impede nocturnal violations. Although the Jews of Venice held important and lucrative positions in the city as physicians, bankers and merchants, they were considered alien and subject to harsh restrictions. This was true of every city of Europe. The nature of the various segregated Jewish areas ranged from affluent quarters, as in Venice, to places of horrible poverty, as in Rome. It was not until the conquest of the Venetian Republic in 1797 by general Napoleon that the restrictions were lifted. The gates were removed and all residents were free to live wherever they chose. By Didier Descouens - Own work, CC BY-SA 4.0, File:Canale di Cannaregio - Viewed from Grand Canal.jpg  There are various suggestions for the origin of the word, whose usage had become extended to segregated and densely packed quarters of other minority groups by 1899. A foundry for cannons was once located on the island that forms part of Venice, where in 1516 the Venetians restricted Jewish residence. Hence, it might be that the term is from the word for foundry in the Venetian dialect, ghèto, ultimately derived from the Latin JACTARE, meaning “to throw,” the definition being extended to mean “to cast metal.” Other possibilities have been put forth: ~~from Italian “borghetto,” “little town,” from “borgo,” a Germanic word which has the English form “burg.” ~~from the Latin GIUDAICETUM, Jewish enclave. This is totally implausible from a phonetic point of view. ~~from the Hebrew “get,” “bill of divorce,” “deed of separation.” This, however, is most likely a folk etymology as the leap from “divorce” to “place of forced isolation” is a mighty one to imagine. ~~from the Yiddish “gehetkes,” “enclosed.” ~~from the Italian word for Egypt, “Egitto,” a reference to the Israelites’ stay in Egypt. Why would the Venetians confuse Jews with Egyptians? The mystery has not been fully resolved. Here is an interesting discourse on the word by famed Oxford etymologist Anatoly Liberman: Why Don't We Know the Origin of the Word Ghetto? | OUPblog

Word story In Italian, ghetto “the quarter of a city where Jews were obliged to live,” dates from 1516 when the Venetians set aside an area for Jewish settlement, shut off from the rest of the city and provided with Christian watchmen. The etymology of ghetto is obscure, but several authorities derive it from Venetian dialect ghèto “(iron) foundry” (there was one at the site of the Jewish quarter).  In English, ghetto in its original meaning dates from the early 17th century. By the late 19th century, ghetto had extended its meaning to “a section of a city, especially a thickly populated slum area, inhabited predominantly by members of an ethnic or other minority group.” Israel Zangwill’s novel Children of the Ghetto (published in 1892) is about the life and experiences of East European Jewish children in the East End of London.

Ghetto, came from Venice Italy in the 1500s which has been answered here very well already, but the most famous Ghetto was in the city of Warsaw in Poland where Jewish residents started an armed revolt to prevent the German transport of Jews to the concentration camps. They held out with very little for a month and killed a lot of German occupation troops, it ended May 16 1943. Ian

It came from the Italian, possibly from getto ‘foundry’ (because the first ghetto was established in 1516 on the site of a foundry in Venice), or from borghetto, diminutive of borgo ‘borough’. Another possible derivation is Ghetto, an island near Venice where Jews were made to live in the 16th century. There seems to be some agreement that the word is Italian, but the exact derivation is under question.

A2A Etymology. The word "ghetto" comes from the Jewish area of Venice, the Venetian Ghetto in Cannaregio, traced to a special use of Venetian ghèto, or "foundry" (there was one near the site of that city's ghetto in 1516). Ghetto - Wikipedia

The word comes from Italian ghèto, meaning foundry. It was originally applied to the Jewish neighborhood surrounding the foundery in Venice. By 1900 ghetto in English meant any poor ethnically dominated neighborhood.
